Comment: Yet another Sicilian! I had 5 White games in this tournament and four of my opponent chose the Sicilian (my opponent in round 7 chose the French).
Yet another Sicilian! I had 5 White games in this tournament and four of my opponent chose the Sicilian (my opponent in round 7 chose the French).
Heading for the Grand Prix, as in my other games.
See round 1 for 2...a6, round 3 for 2...d6 and round 6 for 2...Nc6.
My opponent is developing in a Scheveningen-like manner, quite a solid choice but not especially powerful against the Grand Prix. In my view ...e6/...d5 is the best counter against this opening.

The usual GPA play, White will exchange bishop for knight because knights favour bishops in closed positions such as this one.

The usual GPA play, White will exchange bishop for knight because knights favour bishops in closed positions such as this one.

In GPA style, although 8.d4 may have been an alternative. IfBlack exchanges (which is what he probably should do) White gets a knight on d4 and Black has to retreat the bishop if he doesn't want to lose the bishop pair.

The ...e6/...g6 is also a good setup against the GPA.

Oddly enough, I had the exact same position against blitzkov on GK a few days back. I won't go into further detail because the game is still in progress, but in the post-game analysis of this game with my computer, it indicated 10.f5 as the best move which is what I also played against blitzkov.

Oddly enough, I had the exact same position against blitzkov on GK a few days back. I won't go into further detail because the game is still in progress, but in the post-game analysis of this game with my computer, it indicated 10.f5 as the best move which is what I also played against blitzkov.

But here, I chose a waiting move to see what Black was going to do. I was actually hoping he would commit his king to the kingside so I would have an attacking target. This move may also come in handy if Black is going to place his queen on the a7-g1 diagonal or to avoid a bishop check on d4.
Possibly preparing to castle kingside?

!? Well, let's attack then. On hindsight, I suspect the queen was misplaced here and should have been on f2. I still find it hard to master the finesses of this opening, to know exactly which placement of the pieces is best in which positions. Another example is the question whether to start an attack with e5 or f5, although I'm finding f5 is usually the better choice.
Like in round 6, my opponent tries to castle queenside by hand and/or connect his rooks by moving his king to d7.
?! I try to open some lines now that his king is in the centre, but this is probably just an incorrect pawn sacrifice.
Accepted, and rightly so. Of course the g-pawn was the better choice. Black doesn't have to be afraid of a shattered kingside pawn structure, since his king is not castled there.

Trying to get a bishop exchange as Black's dark-squared bishop looks to be of more use than mine and because it would weaken his defences. Probably 13.Bg5 was better because my move seems to lose a tempo compared to the game. That was also a move that I had considered.
Now that his queen could retake on g7, I didn't like the bishop exchange very much anymore because Black could put the open g-file to use in a kingside attack.
Now that his queen could retake on g7, I didn't like the bishop exchange very much anymore because Black could put the open g-file to use in a kingside attack.

I'm not sure if I like this move, but I should have considered it at least (which I didn't do in the game). It does chase my bishop away and it is what the computer suggests, but it confines his dark-squared bishop very much.

A strange queen manoeuvre. Maybe he's trying to attack on the kingside, but it just seems too slow and ...Bf8 and ...Rg8 will never follow. It allows me to re-organise my pieces and get some counterplay for the pawn.

! The f-pawns become the new target in Black's position. I was starting to feel better about my position here.
Otherwise Black cannot keep his extra pawn.
